metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Qualitative tests for carbon-carbon double bonds, hydroxyl groups, and carboxyl groups

bromine_water_test.name: Bromine Water Test for Alkenes
bromine_water_test.correct: Bromine water (orange-brown) rapidly decolourises when shaken with an alkene due to addition across the C=C double bond. This is a positive test for unsaturation.

turns orange.error: Bromine water starts orange‚Äîa positive test makes it colourless.
turns orange.fix: Alkenes ADD bromine, removing the orange colour.
turns orange.action: Positive test = colour disappears. Orange to colourless.

no colour change.error: No change means no C=C bond (alkane, not alkene).
no colour change.fix: Alkenes cause rapid decolourisation. No change = saturated compound.
no colour change.action: If orange stays, there's no double bond to react with bromine.

turns blue.error: Blue is not involved in bromine water tests.
turns blue.fix: Bromine water: orange ‚Üí colourless with alkenes.
turns blue.action: Don't confuse with other indicator colours.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the bromine water colour change.
persistent.action: Memorise: Br‚ÇÇ(aq) is orange. Alkene adds Br‚ÇÇ ‚Üí dibromo product (colourless).

addition_reaction_alkene.name: Addition Reaction Mechanism
addition_reaction_alkene.correct: The bromine adds across the C=C double bond, breaking the œÄ bond and forming two new C-Br bonds. This is an addition reaction, not substitution.

substitution reaction.error: Substitution replaces atoms; this is addition.
substitution reaction.fix: Addition: atoms add to the molecule. Substitution: atoms replace others.
substitution reaction.action: Count atoms before and after. Addition increases atom count.

elimination reaction.error: Elimination removes atoms; this adds them.
elimination reaction.fix: Alkene + Br‚ÇÇ ADDS bromine. Elimination would create a double bond.
elimination reaction.action: Elimination is the reverse‚Äîcreates alkenes from alcohols.

oxidation reaction.fix: While halogens can oxidise, this bromine test is specifically addition to C=C.
oxidation reaction.action: The mechanism is electrophilic addition, not electron transfer.

persistent.action: Addition = more atoms in product. Substitution = same number, different atoms. Elimination = fewer atoms.

sodium_test_alcohol.name: Sodium Metal Test for Alcohols
sodium_test_alcohol.correct: Sodium metal reacts with the -OH group in alcohols, producing hydrogen gas (effervescence) and sodium alkoxide. This confirms the presence of a hydroxyl group.

produces oxygen gas.fix: The H from -OH is released as H‚ÇÇ gas.
produces oxygen gas.action: Write the equation: 2ROH + 2Na ‚Üí 2RONa + H‚ÇÇ. See the H‚ÇÇ?

no reaction occurs.fix: The -OH hydrogen is acidic enough to react with reactive metals.
no reaction occurs.action: If no reaction, it's not an alcohol (or the Na has oxidised).

produces water.error: Hydrogen gas is produced, not water.
produces water.fix: Na replaces the H in -OH. The H atoms combine to form H‚ÇÇ.
produces water.action: Test the gas: H‚ÇÇ gives a squeaky pop with a lit splint.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the sodium-alcohol reaction.
persistent.action: Balance: 2ROH + 2Na ‚Üí 2RONa + H‚ÇÇ. The -OH hydrogen becomes H‚ÇÇ gas.

alcohol_acidity.name: Relative Acidity of Alcohols
alcohol_acidity.correct: Primary alcohols react faster with sodium than secondary, which react faster than tertiary. This relates to steric hindrance and the accessibility of the -OH group.

tertiary reacts fastest.error: Opposite. Tertiary is most hindered, reacts slowest.
tertiary reacts fastest.fix: More alkyl groups = more steric hindrance = harder for Na to access -OH.
tertiary reacts fastest.action: Primary has least crowding around -OH, so reacts fastest.

all alcohols react equally.fix: Steric effects change how easily Na can reach the -OH group.
all alcohols react equally.action: Draw 1¬∞, 2¬∞, 3¬∞ alcohols. See how crowded the -OH becomes?

secondary reacts fastest.error: Primary is fastest due to least steric hindrance.
secondary reacts fastest.action: Less crowding = easier access = faster reaction.

persistent.gap: You don't understand steric effects on reactivity.
persistent.action: Draw methanol, ethanol, propan-2-ol, 2-methylpropan-2-ol. Note crowding around -OH.

carbonate_test_acid.name: Carbonate Test for Carboxylic Acids
carbonate_test_acid.correct: Carboxylic acids react with sodium carbonate or bicarbonate to produce carbon dioxide gas (effervescence). This confirms the presence of a -COOH group.

produces hydrogen gas.fix: The carbonate provides CO‚ÇÇ. Acid + carbonate ‚Üí salt + water + CO‚ÇÇ.
produces hydrogen gas.action: Test the gas: CO‚ÇÇ turns limewater milky. H‚ÇÇ gives a squeaky pop.

no gas is produced.fix: Acids react with carbonates to release CO‚ÇÇ gas.
no gas is produced.action: If no bubbles, it's not a carboxylic acid.

produces oxygen gas.fix: CO‚ÇÇ comes from the carbonate ion reacting with the acid.
produces oxygen gas.action: Write the ionic equation: 2H‚Å∫ + CO‚ÇÉ¬≤‚Åª ‚Üí H‚ÇÇO + CO‚ÇÇ

persistent.action: General reaction: acid + carbonate ‚Üí salt + water + CO‚ÇÇ. The CO‚ÇÇ bubbles are the positive test.

ph_test_acid.name: pH Testing for Carboxylic Acids
ph_test_acid.correct: Carboxylic acids are weak acids with pH typically 2-5. Universal indicator turns orange/red, and they partially dissociate in water to release H‚Å∫ ions.

pH greater than 7.fix: Carboxylic acids are acidic (release H‚Å∫), so pH < 7.
pH greater than 7.action: Acids = low pH. Bases = high pH. Neutral = 7.

completely dissociate.error: Carboxylic acids are WEAK acids‚Äîpartial dissociation.
completely dissociate.fix: Unlike HCl, carboxylic acids only partially ionise. Equilibrium exists.
completely dissociate.action: Note the reversible arrow: RCOOH ‚áå RCOO‚Åª + H‚Å∫

pH exactly 0.error: Weak acids don't have pH as low as strong acids.
pH exactly 0.fix: Typical carboxylic acid pH is 2-5, not near 0.
pH exactly 0.action: Compare: HCl (strong, pH ~1) vs CH‚ÇÉCOOH (weak, pH ~3).

persistent.gap: You're confusing strong and weak acids.
persistent.action: Weak acid = partial dissociation = higher pH than strong acid of same concentration.

distinguishing_functional_groups.name: Distinguishing Between Functional Groups
distinguishing_functional_groups.correct: A systematic approach tests for different functional groups: bromine water for C=C, sodium for -OH, carbonate for -COOH. The combination of results identifies the compound.

one test identifies all groups.error: Different functional groups need different tests.
one test identifies all groups.fix: Each test is specific: Br‚ÇÇ for alkenes, Na for alcohols, CO‚ÇÉ¬≤‚Åª for acids.
one test identifies all groups.action: Use a decision tree: test ‚Üí result ‚Üí narrows down possibilities.

appearance alone identifies groups.error: Most organic liquids look similar‚Äîchemical tests are needed.
appearance alone identifies groups.fix: Colourless liquids could be many things. Tests reveal functional groups.
appearance alone identifies groups.action: Don't guess from appearance. Run the appropriate chemical tests.

all alcohols and acids react with bromin.error: Bromine water specifically tests for C=C, not -OH or -COOH.
all alcohols and acids react with bromin.fix: Alcohols and acids WITHOUT double bonds won't decolourise bromine water.
all alcohols and acids react with bromin.action: Bromine addition requires C=C. Other groups don't react this way.

persistent.gap: You don't have a systematic testing strategy.
persistent.action: Create a flowchart: Br‚ÇÇ test ‚Üí if positive, contains C=C. Na test ‚Üí if positive, contains -OH. Carbonate test ‚Üí if positive, contains -COOH.

positive_negative_test.name: Interpreting Positive and Negative Tests
positive_negative_test.correct: A positive test (expected observation occurs) confirms the functional group is present. A negative test (no change) indicates the functional group is absent.

negative test means compound is impure.error: Negative means the functional group isn't there.
negative test means compound is impure.fix: A pure compound can give a negative test if it lacks that functional group.
negative test means compound is impure.action: Hexane is pure but gives negative bromine test‚Äîit has no C=C.

positive test identifies the exact compo.error: Positive test identifies the functional GROUP, not the specific compound.
positive test identifies the exact compo.fix: Ethene and propene both give positive bromine tests. Further tests needed to distinguish.
positive test identifies the exact compo.action: Positive test = functional group present. More tests needed for full ID.

all tests should be positive.error: A compound only tests positive for groups it actually contains.
all tests should be positive.fix: Ethanol: positive Na test, negative Br‚ÇÇ test, negative carbonate test.
all tests should be positive.action: The pattern of positives AND negatives tells you the structure.

persistent.action: Record ALL results: positive tests show what's present, negative tests show what's absent.

alkene_tests.title: Testing for Carbon-Carbon Double Bonds
alkene_tests.instructions: Complete the statements about testing for alkenes.

sentences.text: The bromine water test is used to detect the presence of {{d1}} bonds in organic compounds. Bromine water has an {{d2}} colour before the test.

d1.tooltip: What structural feature do alkenes have that alkanes don't?

sentences.text: When an alkene is shaken with bromine water, the solution {{d3}} because bromine {{d4}} across the double bond.

d3.tooltip: What happens to the orange colour?

d4.tooltip: What type of reaction occurs at the double bond?

sentences.text: The product of the bromine water test with ethene is {{d5}}, which is {{d6}}. This confirms the reaction is an addition reaction.

d5.tooltip: Both bromine atoms add to the two carbons that were double-bonded.

d6.tooltip: What colour is the dibromo product?

hydroxyl_tests.title: Testing for Hydroxyl Groups
hydroxyl_tests.instructions: Complete the statements about testing for alcohols.

sentences.text: Sodium metal reacts with the {{d1}} group in alcohols, producing {{d2}} gas which can be identified by a squeaky pop test.

d1.tooltip: What functional group defines an alcohol?

d2.tooltip: What gas gives a squeaky pop with a lit splint?

sentences.text: The equation for the reaction between ethanol and sodium is: 2C‚ÇÇH‚ÇÖOH + 2Na ‚Üí 2C‚ÇÇH‚ÇÖONa + {{d3}}. The ionic product is called sodium {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: What molecule forms when two hydrogen atoms combine?

d4.tooltip: What is the anion called when -OH becomes -O‚Åª?

sentences.text: Primary alcohols react {{d5}} with sodium than tertiary alcohols because there is less {{d6}} around the -OH group.

d5.tooltip: Does less crowding help or hinder the reaction?

d6.tooltip: What do we call the blocking effect of bulky groups?

carboxyl_tests.title: Testing for Carboxyl Groups
carboxyl_tests.instructions: Complete the statements about testing for carboxylic acids.

sentences.text: Carboxylic acids can be identified by their reaction with {{d1}}, which produces {{d2}} gas seen as effervescence (bubbles).

d1.tooltip: Which sodium compound releases CO‚ÇÇ when reacted with acids?

d2.tooltip: What gas comes from the carbonate ion?

sentences.text: The carbon dioxide produced can be confirmed by passing it through {{d3}}, which turns {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: What solution is the standard test for CO‚ÇÇ?

d4.tooltip: What does limewater look like after CO‚ÇÇ is bubbled through?

sentences.text: Carboxylic acids are {{d5}} acids, meaning they only {{d6}} dissociate in water to release H‚Å∫ ions.

d5.tooltip: Do carboxylic acids completely or partially dissociate?

d6.tooltip: What degree of dissociation defines a weak acid?

sentences.text: The pH of a typical carboxylic acid solution is between {{d7}}, indicating an acidic solution.

d7.tooltip: What pH range indicates a weak acid?

alkene_tests.title: Applying Alkene Tests
alkene_tests.instructions: Apply your understanding of alkene testing to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A student has two colourless liquids: hexane and hex-1-ene. When bromine water is added to hex-1-ene, the mixture {{d1}}. When added to hexane, the mixture {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Hex-1-ene has a C=C double bond.

d2.tooltip: Hexane is a saturated alkane with no double bonds.

sentences.text: The reason alkenes react with bromine while alkanes do not is that the {{d3}} bond in alkenes is {{d4}} and can break to allow addition.

d3.tooltip: What type of bond is the second bond in a double bond?

d4.tooltip: Why can the œÄ bond break more easily than the œÉ bond?

sentences.text: A rapid decolourisation of bromine water indicates a {{d5}} test for unsaturation, confirming the presence of a {{d6}} functional group.

d5.tooltip: Does decolourisation confirm or deny the presence of C=C?

d6.tooltip: What functional group does bromine water specifically test for?

hydroxyl_tests.title: Applying Alcohol Tests
hydroxyl_tests.instructions: Apply your understanding of hydroxyl group testing to these scenarios.

sentences.text: When sodium metal is added to propan-1-ol, {{d1}} is observed and {{d2}} gas is evolved.

d1.tooltip: What do you see when gas is produced in a liquid?

d2.tooltip: The H from -OH forms what diatomic gas?

sentences.text: To distinguish between an alcohol and an alkane, the sodium test is useful because alkanes {{d3}} with sodium while alcohols {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Do C-H bonds react with sodium?

d4.tooltip: What happens when -OH reacts with Na?

sentences.text: The reactivity order of alcohols with sodium is {{d5}} > {{d6}} > tertiary, due to increasing steric hindrance.

d5.tooltip: Which alcohol type has least crowding around -OH?

d6.tooltip: Which comes between primary and tertiary?

carboxyl_tests.title: Applying Carboxylic Acid Tests
carboxyl_tests.instructions: Apply your understanding of carboxyl group testing to these scenarios.

sentences.text: When ethanoic acid is added to sodium hydrogen carbonate, {{d1}} is observed. The gas produced turns limewater {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What happens when CO‚ÇÇ is released?

d2.tooltip: What does CO‚ÇÇ do to limewater?

sentences.text: Both alcohols and carboxylic acids contain {{d3}}, but only carboxylic acids react with carbonates because their hydrogen is more {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: What structural feature do alcohols and carboxylic acids share?

d4.tooltip: The -COOH hydrogen is more easily released as H‚Å∫ than the -OH hydrogen.

sentences.text: A compound gives a negative bromine water test but a positive carbonate test. This indicates the compound contains a {{d5}} group but no {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: What functional group gives a positive carbonate test?

d6.tooltip: What would give a positive bromine water test?

sentences.text: The pH of a 0.1 M ethanoic acid solution is approximately {{d7}}, which is {{d8}} than the pH of 0.1 M HCl.

d7.tooltip: Weak acids have pH higher than strong acids at same concentration.

d8.tooltip: Weak acid = less H‚Å∫ = higher pH.

alkene_tests.title: Mastering Alkene Analysis
alkene_tests.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of alkene testing.

sentences.text: A common misconception is that all organic compounds decolourise bromine water. In fact, only compounds with {{d1}} react this way, because the reaction requires a {{d2}} bond to break.

d1.tooltip: What structural feature is essential for bromine addition?

d2.tooltip: What bond breaks during addition to a double bond?

sentences.text: The bromine water test is classified as a qualitative test because it indicates {{d3}} of a functional group, not {{d4}} of that group present.

d4.tooltip: Quantitative tells us amounts; qualitative tells us yes/no.

sentences.text: To confirm an unknown is specifically ethene rather than any alkene, the bromine test shows {{d5}}, then {{d6}} analysis would reveal the molecular formula.

d5.tooltip: What does the bromine test confirm?

d6.tooltip: One test identifies the group; you need more tests for the specific compound.

hydroxyl_tests.title: Mastering Alcohol Analysis
hydroxyl_tests.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of hydroxyl group testing.

sentences.text: Both alcohols and carboxylic acids react with sodium metal because both contain an {{d1}} atom that can be replaced. However, carboxylic acids react {{d2}} because their O-H bond is more polar.

d1.tooltip: Which specific atom is replaced by sodium?

d2.tooltip: More polar O-H = more acidic = faster reaction with Na.

sentences.text: The sodium test cannot distinguish between {{d3}} and {{d4}}‚Äîboth produce hydrogen gas. Additional tests like the carbonate test are needed.

d3.tooltip: Which functional group has -OH and reacts with Na?

d4.tooltip: Which other functional group contains -OH and reacts with Na?

sentences.text: To identify an unknown as specifically propan-1-ol, tests must show: positive sodium test ({{d5}} present), negative bromine test (no {{d6}}), and negative carbonate test (not an acid).

d5.tooltip: What functional group does the sodium test detect?

d6.tooltip: What would give a positive bromine water test?

carboxyl_tests.title: Mastering Carboxylic Acid Analysis
carboxyl_tests.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of carboxyl group testing.

sentences.text: The carbonate test is specific to carboxylic acids because alcohols are {{d1}} acidic to react with carbonates. Only {{d2}} acids can protonate the carbonate ion.

d1.tooltip: Alcohols have -OH but are they acidic enough?

d2.tooltip: Which organic acids react with carbonates?

sentences.text: A compound tests positive with both sodium (H‚ÇÇ evolved) and carbonate (CO‚ÇÇ evolved). This pattern indicates a {{d3}} group, which contains {{d4}} that can react with both reagents.

d3.tooltip: What functional group is acidic enough for both tests?

d4.tooltip: What makes -COOH react with both Na and carbonate?

sentences.text: A systematic approach to identify functional groups uses multiple tests: bromine water tests for {{d5}}, sodium tests for {{d6}}, and carbonate tests for -COOH.

d5.tooltip: What does bromine water specifically detect?

d6.tooltip: What functional group produces H‚ÇÇ with sodium?

sentences.text: The combination of test results creates a 'fingerprint' for functional groups: an alcohol gives {{d7}} Na test, {{d8}} Br‚ÇÇ test, and negative carbonate test.

d8.tooltip: Does a simple alcohol (no C=C) react with bromine water?

bromine_water_test.title: Bromine Water Test
bromine_water_test.content: Bromine water (Br‚ÇÇ dissolved in water) is orange-brown. When shaken with an alkene, the bromine adds across the C=C double bond, forming a colourless dibromo product. This rapid decolourisation is a positive test for unsaturation.

addition_reaction_alkene.title: Addition Reaction
addition_reaction_alkene.content: In addition reactions, atoms add to a molecule by breaking a œÄ bond. The alkene's double bond (one œÉ + one œÄ) loses the œÄ bond as bromine atoms add to each carbon, forming two new C-Br bonds.
keyPoints: œÄ bond breaks to allow addition
No atoms are lost from the molecule

sodium_test_alcohol.title: Sodium Metal Test
sodium_test_alcohol.content: Sodium metal reacts with the -OH group in alcohols: 2ROH + 2Na ‚Üí 2RONa + H‚ÇÇ. Hydrogen gas is evolved (squeaky pop test), and sodium alkoxide forms. This confirms hydroxyl groups.

alcohol_acidity.title: Alcohol Reactivity
alcohol_acidity.content: Primary alcohols react fastest with sodium, followed by secondary, then tertiary. This is due to steric hindrance‚Äîmore alkyl groups around -OH block access for the sodium.
keyPoints: All produce H‚ÇÇ, but at different rates

carbonate_test_acid.title: Carbonate Test
carbonate_test_acid.content: Carboxylic acids react with sodium carbonate or bicarbonate to produce CO‚ÇÇ gas: 2RCOOH + Na‚ÇÇCO‚ÇÉ ‚Üí 2RCOONa + H‚ÇÇO + CO‚ÇÇ. The effervescence and positive limewater test confirm -COOH.

ph_test_acid.title: pH of Carboxylic Acids
ph_test_acid.content: Carboxylic acids are weak acids (pH 2-5) because they only partially dissociate: RCOOH ‚áå RCOO‚Åª + H‚Å∫. Universal indicator turns orange/red, but pH is higher than strong acids.

distinguishing_functional_groups.title: Systematic Testing
distinguishing_functional_groups.content: Different functional groups require different tests. Use bromine water for C=C, sodium for -OH, and carbonate for -COOH. The pattern of positive and negative results identifies the functional group(s) present.

positive_negative_test.title: Interpreting Results
positive_negative_test.content: A positive test (expected change occurs) confirms presence of a functional group. A negative test (no change) confirms absence. Both results are informative for identification.
